deIdi2b2.TEXT:
Record date: 2081-03-21
Plastic Surgery Consult Note
Chief PRS: Dr. Anthony Giles Senior PRS: Dr. Dawn Julian Junior resident: Dr. Oneida Norwood
Date: 3/21/2081
Patient Name: Vieira, Nathan MRN: 0666729
CC: Consult for radial artery harvest
HPI: 74 RHD M with coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, Type II DM, peripheral arterial disease and prior cigarette abuse admitted to the Vascular Surgery service on 3/8 with critical limb ischemia. On 03/09/2081, he underwent peroneal and popliteal angioplasty with thrombolysis of the femoral-popliteal bypass graft and stenting of the proximal anastomosis by Dr. Godfrey. This was complicated by a postoperative MI. 03/15/2081, cardiac catheterization is significant for left main and multivessel coronary artery disease, and CABG was planned. Of note, his cath was complicated by pseudoaneurysm of the right brachial artery at the point of access. He was evaluated by SonoSite by the cardiac surgical PA, and was found to have no available venous conduit secondary to his multiple lower extremity procedures. We are therefore consulted for radial artery harvest.
PMH: CAD-remote, silent myocardial infarction
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Diabetes Mellitus Type II
Peripheral Neuropathy
Peripheral Arterial Disease-S/P (R) femoral to below knee popliteal BPG with PTFE, 02/2078
-S/P (L) femoral to below knee popliteal BPG with PTFE, 04/2078
-S/P (L) open thrombectomy femoral-popliteal BPG, 12/2078
-S/P (L) femoral artery cutdown, graft thrombecomy, patch angioplasty of CFA, patch angioplasty of proximal BPG, angiogram of LLE, balloon angioplasty of posterior tibial artery, balloon angioplasty of peronral artery, balloon angioplasty of tibioperoneal artery with placement of stent, 05/2080
-S/P (L) popliteal exploration with graft thrombectomy and stent placement of proximal graft, 05/2080
-precedure c/b LLE MRSA requiring I&D and VAC dressing x 2, 07/2080
Prostate Cancer
Neurogenic Bladder
Psoriasis
Shoulder Surgery-S/P (L)
Tonsillectomy
MEDS: Acetaminophen (tylenol ) 325-650 MG PO Q6H
Acetylcysteine 20%(200 mg/ml) 1200 MG PO BID
Acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) 325 MG PO DAILY
Captopril 6.25 MG PO TID
Carvedilol (coreg) 3.125 MG PO BID
Collagenase (santyl ) 1 APPLICATION TOP TID
Digoxin 0.25 MG IV Q6H
Docusate sodium (colace ) 100 MG PO BID
Furosemide (lasix ) 60 MG PO BID
Heparin cardiac sliding scale iv 500-1500 Units/Hr IV CONTINUOUS INFUSION
Insulin aspart (novolog ) 14 UNITS SC QPM BEFORE SUPPER
Insulin aspart (novolog ) 15 UNITS SC QAM BEFORE BREAKFAST
Insulin aspart (novolog ) Sliding Scale SC TID AC
Insulin nph human 20 UNITS SC QAM BEFORE BREAKFAST
Nitroglycerin paste 2% (nitrol paste ) 1 INCHES TOP Q4H
Sennosides (senna tablets ) 2 TAB PO Q12H
Simvastatin (zocor ) 40 MG PO DAILY
Vancomycin hcl (vancocin hcl ) 1000 MG IV BID
ALL: Adhesive tape (Rash)
Physical Exam: General: Alert, pleasant, NAD RUE: Palpable 2+ radial pulse, weakly dopplerable ulnar pulse. Allen’s test: prior to compression of radial artery, SpO2 100%. During compression, signal lost by probe within seconds. Upon release, signal regained, SpO2 again 100%. Localized edema of upper arm, no obvious pulsatile mass. LUE: Well-healed scar anterior shoulder from prior surgery. Palpable 2+ radial, 1+ ulnar pulses. Allen’s test: prior to compression of radial artery, SpO2 99%. Remained 99% with compression of radial artery X2 minutes. Clinical Allen’s test: somewhat sluggish (5-6 seconds) pinking up of the exsanguinated hand upon release of the ulnar artery.
Labs/studies:
WBC 6.3 (4.5-11.0) th/cmm
HCT 32.4 L (41.0-53.0) %
HGB 10.7 L (13.5-17.5) gm/dl
RBC 4.04 L (4.50-5.90) mil/cmm
PLT 245 (150-400) th/cumm
MCV 80 (80-100) fl
MCH 26.5 (26.0-34.0) pg/rbc
MCHC 33.0 (31.0-37.0) g/dl
RDW 16.1 H (11.5-14.5) %
PT 14.3 H (10.3-13.2) sec
PT-INR 1.3
APTT 75.4 H (21.0-33.0) sec
Plasma Sodium 137 (135-145) mmol/L
Plasma Potassium 4.3 (3.4-4.8) mmol/L
Plasma Chloride 103 (100-108) mmol/L
Plasma Carbon Dioxide 22.9 L (23.0-31.9) mmol/L
Plasma Anion GAP 11 (3-15) mmol/L
Calcium 9.1 (8.5-10.5) mg/dl
Phosphorus 4.2 (2.6-4.5) mg/dl
Magnesium 1.6 (1.4-2.0) meq/L
Plasma Urea Nitrogen 11 (8-25) mg/dl
Plasma Creatinine 1.05 (0.60-1.50) mg/dl
eGFR >60 mL/min/1.73m2
Assessment: 74 M with PVD and recent MI, preop for CABG sometime next week. His left radial artery may be safe to use for conduit. His right is not usable.
Recs: - Preop per Cardiac Surgery Service - Patient to be seen by Dr. Queen Olivares, Plastic Surgery Fellow. She will not be available for radial artery harvest on Thursday of next week.
Discussed with Dr. Queen Olivares, Plastic Surgery Fellow.
__________________________
Oneida Norwood MD, PGY-2
Resident in General Surgery
Pager-56956
Patient seen and examined. Addendum to above note on 3/22/81:
ROS: Denies HA, visual change Denies CP, SOB, palpitations Denies n/v, GI upset Denies h/o seizures Currently has LLE wound (from recent procedure) States is R. handed, likes to golf, states hands are always cold and sometimes turn "blue"-no pain associatd w/ symptoms Denies new onset of UE/LE weakness
Plan: Allen's test on RUE is abnormal and is consistent with a dominant radial artery, however, left appears to be fine. Will likely attempt harvest of LUE radial artery-will retest Allen's test intraop as welll Please avoid any additional needle sticks or blood draws from the LUE Please let the plastic team know ASAP of the surgery date so that our schedule can be coordinated with the CABG surgery
